content: The "Border Health Security Act of 2011" may be cited as the official title of this Act. Key findings are outlined in Section 2. The United States-Mexico border region, with a population of 14,538,209 people, faces significant public health challenges including low health insurance coverage, limited access to healthcare, and high rates of diseases like tuberculosis, diabetes, and obesity. The 2009 H1N1 outbreak highlighted the need for strong public health efforts at the border to protect Americans and enhance biosecurity. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission has been a vital bi-national institution for 11 years. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission plays a crucial role in addressing cross-border health issues. Two key initiatives include the Early Warning Infectious Disease Surveillance (EWIDS) and the Ventanillas de Salud program, which provide early detection of infectious diseases and health education to Mexican citizens in the US. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission requires additional resources and modifications to provide stronger leadership in optimizing health and quality of life along the border, reaching an estimated 1,500,000 people in the US. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act is being amended. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act is being amended to serve as an independent body to recommend and implement initiatives that solve border health issues. Additionally, the Chair of the Commission shall provide advice and recommendations to Congress on relevant issues. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act is being amended to allow the Chair of the Commission to provide advice and recommendations to Congress on relevant issues, regardless of whether a request is made. Section 8 is being redesignated as section 13, and section 7 is being replaced with new language. Section 8 is being redesignated as section 13, and section 7 is being replaced with new language regarding Border Health Grants. The term 'eligible entity' includes various organizations in the United States-Mexico Border Area. Grants will be awarded to these entities to address health priorities outlined in the strategic and operational plans. An eligible entity in the United States-Mexico Border Area can apply for a grant from the Secretary of Health and Human Services to fund programs related to maternal and child health, primary care, infectious disease testing, public health infrastructure, health promotion, oral health, mental health, substance abuse, and prevalent health conditions. The eligible entity in the United States-Mexico Border Area can apply for a grant from the Secretary of Health and Human Services for various health-related programs, including workforce training, community health workers, health disparities, environmental health, health education, outreach services, and trauma care. The eligible entity in the United States-Mexico Border Area can apply for a grant from the Secretary of Health and Human Services for various health-related programs, including trauma care, health research, epidemiology, cross-border health surveillance, obesity, crisis communication, domestic violence, substance abuse, health literacy, cancer, and community-based participatory research on border health issues. Other programs may be determined appropriate by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Amounts provided are meant to supplement, not supplant existing funding. Amounts awarded to eligible entities in the US-Mexico Border Area must supplement, not replace, other funds for specified health programs. "Grants for early warning infectious disease surveillance projects in the border area are provided under Section 8." The term 'eligible entity' refers to various organizations in the United States-Mexico Border Area. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants for infectious disease surveillance activities in this area. Eligible entities must submit an application to receive a grant and use the funds for specified purposes. An eligible entity receiving a grant must use the funds for infectious disease surveillance plans, coordination with US agencies and Mexico/Canada, improving infrastructure, creating a health alert network, and educating clinicians and epidemiologists. The activities funded by the grant include educating and training healthcare professionals, implementing electronic data systems for coordinating incident response, providing infectious disease testing in the US-Mexico Border Area, and carrying out additional activities as identified by relevant health authorities. "SEC. 9. PLANS, REPORTS, AUDITS, AND BY-LAWS." The Commission must prepare a binational strategic plan every 5 years, outlining health-related priority areas and recommendations for goals and actions to address them. This plan is to be submitted to the Secretary, Congress, and the Mexican legislature. The Commission is required to develop an evaluation framework with indicators to measure progress towards its objectives. It must also create a work plan and budget based on a strategic plan, with evaluations conducted by the Government Accountability Office. Biannual reports are to be submitted to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Commission must provide biannual reports to the Secretary of Health and Human Services on border health issues, with independent policy recommendations. The Secretary will then share the report with Congress. Additionally, the Secretary must prepare an annual audited financial report for all assets expended by the Commission. The Commission is required to develop bylaws within 6 months of enactment to ensure compliance with the section's requirements and submit work plans and bylaws to Congress. The Government Accountability Office will submit an evaluation of the work plan and by-laws to Congress. SEC. 10. BINATIONAL HEALTH INFRASTRUCTURE AND HEALTH INSURANCE. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will contract the Institute of Medicine to study binational health infrastructure between the United States and Mexico, and the United States and Canada, including trauma care and health insurance efforts. The Institute will gather input from border health experts and insurance issuers. A report with recommendations on improving binational health must be submitted to the Secretary and Congress within a year. The Institute of Medicine will study ways to enhance binational health infrastructure and health insurance efforts between the United States and Mexico, as well as the United States and Canada. The text discusses the coordination of plans, systems, and activities for all hazard preparedness in the United States-Mexico Border area. It emphasizes the need for coordination with Federal, State, and local authorities in both countries. Additionally, it mentions the potential establishment of a health alert system to monitor disease clusters, health threats, disasters, and bioterrorism along the border. "Authorization of appropriations for all hazard preparedness in the United States-Mexico Border area." The Act authorizes $31,000,000 annually for various activities, including funding for functions in Mexico and administration of US activities. Additionally, funds are allocated for border health activities, grant programs, and reports by the Institute of Medicine and Government Accountability Office.
